Description: Fragment of limestone relief from the tomb of Sety I: the hieroglyphs are painted in full colour and carved in raised relief on a white background. The fragment contains parts of five vertical lines of hieroglyphic text.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tomb of Sety I, Tomb 17. From the lower parts of a wall of one of the lower corridors (corridor H). The signs face towards the burial chamber, and since they face left, this shows that this fragment came from the north wall of the corridor.
Curator's comments: The high standard of workmanship in the royal tombs reflects the centrality of the king in material as well as political culture. In terms of decorum, certain texts and scenes such as this were restricted to royal monuments. Bibliography: W.V Davies, 'Egyptian Hieroglyphs, Reading the Past' (London, 1987), front cover; E. Hornung and E. Staehelin, 'Sethos: Ein Phamonengrab' (Basel, 1991), 56, fig. 39.
Bibliographic references: Parkinson 1999 / Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and Decipherment (5)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1977 London, BM, Animals in Art 2017-2018 20 Oct-18 Jun, Antikenmuseum Basel und Sammlung Ludwig, Fascinating Pharaonic Tombs.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Sir John Gardner Wilkinson
